user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GenericWrite_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_GenericWrite_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *buffer, size_t nbytes, int32 timeout)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    ssize_t                         os_result;
    uint32                          operation;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    if (nbytes > 0)
    {
        operation = OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE;

        /*
         * If filehandle is set with O_NONBLOCK, then must call select() here.
         *
         * The "selectable" field should be set false for those file handles
         * which the underlying OS does not support select() on.
         *
         * Note that a timeout will not work unless selectable is true.
         */
        if (impl->selectable)
        {
            return_code = OS_SelectSingle_Impl(token, &operation, timeout);
        }

        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS && (operation & OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE) != 0)
        {
            /* on some system libraries for which the write() argument is not
             * qualified correctly, it needs to be case to a void* here */
            os_result = write(impl->fd, GENERIC_IO_CONST_DATA_CAST buffer, nbytes);
            if (os_result < 0)
            {
                OS_DEBUG("write: %s\n", strerror(errno));
                return_code = OS_ERROR;
            }
            else
            {
                /* type conversion from ssize_t to int32 for return */
                return_code = (int32)os_result;
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_GenericWrite_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define GENERIC_IO_CONST_DATA_CAST 
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The function takes a pointer to const OS_object_token_t and only reads token->obj_idx to return it; neither the pointer parameter nor the pointed-to object is modified.
